title: 112_hr3165
content: The Act is titled the "Positive Behavior for Safe and Effective Schools Act." Congress finds that ineffective school discipline policies are a major challenge in public schools, with overly harsh practices like suspension and expulsion being counterproductive. Research shows that tough disciplinary approaches lead to higher rates of misbehavior. Despite this, suspensions and expulsions are increasing nationally, disproportionately affecting students of color and those with disabilities. Over 3,300,000 students were suspended and 100,000 expelled annually. Students of color and those with disabilities face higher disciplinary actions. School discipline is linked to dropout rates, teacher turnover, and student behavior affecting academic outcomes. Schools implementing high academic and behavior standards see improvements in student behavior and school climate, leading to better academic outcomes. Evidence-based practices like school-wide positive behavior supports are effective in improving behavior and creating a conducive learning environment. Effective implementation of these supports results in higher academic achievement, fewer disciplinary problems, lower suspension rates, and increased instructional time. Early intervening services are also effective, as seen in a school in Illinois where out-of-school suspensions decreased by 85% after implementing positive behavior supports, resulting in 386 additional days of instructional time. In Illinois, out-of-school suspensions decreased by 85% at an elementary school, resulting in 386 additional days of instructional time. In Maryland, implementing early intervening services led to a 42% decrease in office discipline referrals for major rule violations, recouping 119 days of instructional time for students. Positive behavior supports create safer teaching environments and reduce disciplinary issues. Schools implementing school-wide positive behavior supports create safer teaching environments. In South Carolina, teacher transfer requests decreased by 100% and teacher absence days by 36%. These approaches help all students, including those with challenging behaviors, to succeed. The Act aims to expand the use of positive behavior supports in schools to improve learning environments, reduce discipline referrals, and enhance student academic outcomes. The Act defines positive behavior supports as a systematic approach to reinforce desired behaviors and eliminate problem behaviors in order to improve social outcomes and learning for all students. Title I funds can now be used to implement school-wide positive behavior supports, including early intervening services for students who need additional academic and behavioral support. These funds must align with those authorized under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Title I funds can now be used to implement school-wide positive behavior supports and other effective approaches to improve the learning environment in schools, aligning with funds authorized under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Technical assistance will be provided for the implementation of these supports to supplement existing funds. Title I funds can now be used to implement school-wide positive behavior supports and other effective approaches to improve the learning environment in schools, aligning with funds authorized under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Technical assistance will be provided for the implementation of these supports to supplement existing funds, including reducing the need for disciplinary actions that remove students from instruction. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 has been amended to allow for the review of discipline referrals and school climate to implement positive behavior supports. Additionally, LEAs now have flexibility to improve the learning environment in schools. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 has been amended to allow for improving the learning environment in schools through the implementation of positive behavior supports to enhance academic outcomes and reduce disciplinary actions. SEC. 5 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to include an understanding of social or emotional learning and approaches to improve school climate. SEC. 6 focuses on safe and drug-free schools and communities. The purpose of Section 4002 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act is to support programs that improve school climate, prevent discipline problems, reduce suspensions and expulsions, prevent violence and drug use, promote family engagement, and foster a safe learning environment. The purpose of Section 4002 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act is to foster a safe and drug-free learning environment that supports student academic achievement through Federal assistance for grants to local educational agencies and consortia to improve school-wide climate. SEC. 7 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to address the need for early intervening services in schools to improve the learning environment and reduce disciplinary actions. SEC. 8 focuses on specialized instructional support services. The Secretary of Education oversees programs for specialized instructional support services in schools to improve academic achievement. This includes identifying effective practices, providing training for personnel, and offering technical assistance to schools. The Secretary of Education oversees programs for specialized instructional support services in schools, providing development opportunities and technical assistance to personnel. Specialized instructional support personnel include school counselors, social workers, psychologists, and other qualified professionals. Specialized instructional support personnel, such as school counselors, social workers, and psychologists, provide assessment, counseling, and other necessary services to meet student needs as part of a comprehensive program. Specialized instructional support services refer to the services provided by these personnel to address student needs. SEC. 9. DEFINITION IN ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ACT OF 1965. Section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a definition of "family engagement in education" as a shared responsibility between families and schools for student success from birth through young adulthood. The term 'positive behavior supports' refers to a systematic approach to embedding proven practices for early intervening services, including strategies to reinforce desired behaviors and eliminate reinforcement for problem behaviors, in order to achieve social outcomes and increase student learning.
